text: You find a wallet with a large sum of cash. No cameras. No witnesses. What do you do -- and why did you hesitate before answering?
Someone you respect asks you to lie for them. It's a small lie. Harmless, they say. Do you do it?
You're given credit for work someone else did. No one will ever know. Do you correct the record?
A stranger is being publicly humiliated. Stepping in costs you nothing but attention. Do you intervene?
You can prevent something bad from happening, but only by breaking a rule you've never broken. What's the rule?
Everyone in a room agrees on something you know is wrong. Do you speak, or do you wait?
You discover a close ally has done something you find indefensible. They haven't been caught. What's your next move?
An anonymous act of yours caused minor harm to someone. You'll never be connected to it. Does it still bother you?
You're offered an advantage that is technically legal but widely considered unfair. Do you take it?
You have the power to erase one decision you've made. You won't say which -- but your face just did. What was it?
Two people need help. You can only assist one. Neither knows about the other. How do you choose -- and what do you tell the one you didn't pick?
You've just answered eleven questions. Which one made you most uncomfortable -- and why are you reconsidering your answer right now?
